OPERATING PROCEDURES
Operating procedures describe all employee tasks, data to be recorded, operating conditions to be maintained, and safety and health precautions to be utilized in operation of the process containing regulated substances.  The procedures need to be technically accurate and will result in safe operation of the facility.  In addition, they need to be understandable to the employees and/or contractors.  The procedures must be updated as changes are made to the facility or to the operating limits of the system.  The regulations require that the employer annually certify that the operating procedures are current and accurate.

All phases of system operation must be covered by written procedures.  Specifically, procedures must be available for:

¿	Initial startup;
¿	Normal operation;
¿	Temporary operations as the need arises;
¿	Emergency shutdown;
¿	Normal shutdown; and
¿	Startup following a turnaround, or after an emergency shutdown.

The procedures contain process operation limits and provide information of the consequences of deviation from these limits and the steps required to correct any deviations.  Safety and health measures are included in the procedures to warn employees of po

This technical study was conducted to fulfill the hazard assessment (off-site consequence analysis) requirements of the united supermarkets facility. The regulated material present at the facility and the focus of this is anhydrous ammonia. Ammonia is used as the refrigerant in the refrigeration system that provides cooling of cold storage of food products.
The maximum intended inventory at the facility is approximately 22,304 pounds of ammonia used as a refrigerant within a closed system. The system, consists of piping, valves, and equipment, cycles ammonia through various physical states (high pressure liquid, low pressure liquid, low pressure vapor, high pressure vapor, then back to high pressure liquid) in order to provide refrigeration for cold storage and freezer storage and dock operations.
As part of this analysis, the emergency response planning guidelines concentration level 2 (ERPG-2) was used as a toxic endpoint to quantify off-site impact for the facility. The ERPG-2 was developed to provide estimates of concentration ranges within which adverse health effects can be observed. Table 1-1 summarizes the maximum downwind distances at the ERPG-2 and the estimated populations that are at risk to being exposed to the ERPG-2 concentration for each release. The at risk population numbers are the estimated number of people within the radius of the maximum downwind distance reached by the plume in all wind directions.

INTRODUCTION
In response to the city of Roanoke Emergency Management Agency, the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA), and the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA), this Process Safety Management/Risk Management Program (PSM/RMP) document has been developed for the Llano Logistics, L.P. facility.  This document has been

prepared to satisfy multiple regulations and is governed by the following agencies:

¿	OSHA'S Code of Regulations, OSHA 29 CFR 1910.119, Process Safety Management of Highly Hazardous Chemicals (PSM).

¿	Federal EPA's, Code of Federal Regulations, Title 40, Part 68, Accidental Release Prevention Requirements:  Risk Management Programs Under Clean Air Act Section 112(r), Program 3 Requirements (RMP)

¿	General Duty Clause, Title 40, Clean Air Act, Section 112(r)(1).

The purpose of this document is to:

¿	Increase the protection of public health, the environment, and facility employees by ensuring proper emergency response and mitigation procedures when handling regulated substances.

¿	Assist Llano Logistics, L.P. and local government agencies in their communication and coordination efforts to improve facility safety while handling regulated substances.

This document addresses Llano Logistics, L.P. administrative and operational programs to prevent accidents related to regulated substances and to reduce potential risks.  The regulated substance of concern and focus of this document is anhydrous ammonia.  Ammonia is used to provide refrigeration for warehouse cold/freezer storage, and dock operations.

This Executive Summary contains tables outlining the PSM/RMP sections. It includes the purpose, frequency of use, responsibilities and requirements, and forms for each section of the
PSM/RMP  program.
FACILITY DESCRIPTION
Llano Logistics, L.P. operates a refrigeration system utilizing anhydrous ammonia as the primary refrigerant.  The refrigeration system is located in the main building.

Mechanical refrigeration is a thermodynamic process where the refrigerant, ammonia, is used as a heat exchanging fluid to maintain a desired temperature in an enclosed environment.  The refrigeration cycle consists of evaporation, compression, condensation, and expansion.  Evaporation and condensation are designed to alter the quantity of energy associated with r

efrigerant.  Compression and expansion are designed to change the availability of the associated energy.  The refrigeration cycle is a closed-loop process.  The ammonia refrigeration cycle utilizes fluid temperature, pressure, and latent heat of vaporization for cooling.  The refrigeration system utilizes these phenomenons to remove heat from a desired area, and then to discard that heat, through condensation, to an area where it is of no consequence.

The Llano Logistics, L.P. facility utilizes ammonia refrigeration to cool various storage areas.  The refrigeration system contains the following equipment:  one high pressure thermosyphon receiver, one high temperature recirculator, one low temperature recirculator, four screw compressors, one evaporative condenser, and thirteen evaporators.

PROCESS SAFETY INFORMATION
Complete and accurate written information concerning process chemicals, process technology, and process equipment is essential to an effective PSM/RMP program a

nd to other aspects such as the Process Hazard Analysis (PHA).  The information to be compiled about the chemicals needs to be comprehensive enough for an accurate assessment of the fire and explosion characteristics, reactivity hazards, the health and safety hazards to workers, and the corrosion effects on process equipment as well as monitoring and safety related equipment.  MSDS information can provide a portion of the required data but other information will be required.

Process technology information is also required.  This includes information on the amount of hazardous material stored and used at the facility as well as operating limits for the process.  Diagrams of the system and information on all of the equipment utilized in the system are required.  Piping and instrumentation diagrams (P&IDs) are included in the Process Safety Information.

PROCESS HAZARD ANALYSIS
The Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) is the basis for many of the decisions and procedures associated with an effective PSM/RMP program.  It is a systematic effort to determine the potential hazards associated with the process and to evaluate mitigation alternatives including equipment modifications, procedural modifications, training, and administrative controls.  An effective PHA considers and analyzes the potential consequences associated with a release of the hazardous materials including fires, explosions, and exposure of people to toxic materials.  It focuses on equipment, instrumentation, utilities, human actions, and external events.

To ensure that both operator safety as well as off-site safety is addressed, the HAZOP (Guide Word method) and the "What-If" Checklist analysis are conducted during

tential risks and protective action that should be taken.

EMPLOYEE TRAINING
All employees, including maintenance and contractor employees involved with regulated substances (i.e. ammonia), need to fully understand the health and safety hazards associated with the chemical with which they are working.  This will allow them to better protect themselves, fellow employees, and the neighboring communities.  In addition to the normal awareness training, which informs personnel of the hazards of the chemical and the safety precautions to use, training in operating procedures and practices, emergency response, and other required management controls are required.

Employees must identify the personnel who require training, develop a training protocol with procedures and objectives, and maintain a record of personnel training.  Regular evaluation of the training program must be accomplished to ensure that it is appropriate information to the employees in a useful and understandable way.

If outside employees (maintenance or contract) are performing work which might impact the ammonia refrigeration system, the Safety Supervisor has an obligation to assure that they have been properly trained by their employer and have been informed of any hazardous conditions and the proper procedures to be utilized at the facility.

MECHANICAL INTEGRITY

This program will consist of routine (scheduled) inspection, testing, overhaul, and replacement as needed.  Equipment must be categorized and ranked with respect to the maintenance involved.  This maintenance and inspection information will include all equipment such as storage tanks, compressors, condensers, evaporators, process piping relief and vent systems, fire protection system components, emergency shutdown systems, and alarms.  Each component must be place

INCIDENT INVESTIGATION
Incident investigation is the process of identifying the underlying causes of incidents and implementing steps to prevent similar events from occurring.  It is required that employees will recognize and investigate events that resulted in or could reasonably have resulted in a hazardous chemical release. Employers must develop in-house capabilities to investigate incidents that occur in their facilities.  A team must be assembled by Llano Logistics, L.P. and trained to collect and document information related to any incident.  Usually a multi-disciplinary team is better able to gather the facts and evaluate "what happened and why

."  All employees with information should be interviewed and other facts should be gathered to develop a complete picture of the facts concerning the incident.  Recommendations are then developed for changes in equipment, procedures, or safety systems to prevent recurrence of the event.

EMERGENCY PLANNING AND RESPONSE
Emergency plans are required in case there is a release of ammonia (or other emergency such as fire or earthquake).  Employers must select a formal plan on how to handle an emergency situation and also a plan to educate employees as to what they should do.  This plan must be detailed and include procedures for notifying local authorities and following up with written accident reports, should the release meet or exceed the reportable quantity (100 pounds of ammonia).  Many local site factors will be included in the ammonia emergency and fire prevention plan.  Llano Logistics, L.P. has a stated policy of responding to all leaks to determine the proper response.  Llano Logistics, L.P. will respond to and mitigate all leaks with

in the limits of training and with the proper use of PPE.
